Messages.Author: Gaelle Fer-Arslan
Messages.Content: Liebe Studierende/Dear Students, ihr könnt noch bis zum 12.07.2024 an der Evaluation der Lehrveranstaltung "Computergraphik 2" des Sommersemesters 2024 teilnehmen. Bitte nehmt Euch die Zeit, die Frage Bögen auszufüllen. Danke! You can still take part in the evaluation of the course "Computer Graphics 2" for the summer semester 2024 until July 12, 2024. Please take the time to fill out the questionnaires. Thank you! ------------------------------ Beiliegend erhaltet Ihr den Link der lösungsbasierten Umfrage für die Evaluation der Lehrveranstaltung "Computergraphik 2" des Sommersemesters 2024: Computergraphik 2: https://befragung.tu-berlin.de/evasys/online.php?p=CZ6RM   Die Umfrage dauert jeweils ca. eine halbe Stunde und ist bis zum 12. Juli 2024 freigeschaltet. Durch Eure Teilnahme leistet Ihr einen wichtigen Beitrag zur Qualitätssicherung des Lehrangebotes. Desto mehr Kursteilnehmer und -teilnehmerinnen auf die Umfrage antworten, desto aussagekräftiger sind die Daten am Ende. Die Rückmeldungen werden vom Evaluationsteam der Fakultät IV gesammelt und in anonymer Form ausgewertet. Die Ergebnisse der Evaluation werden zum Schluss per E-Mail an die Dozenten und Dozentinnen mitgeteilt. ****************************************************************************** Please find, enclosed, the link to the online survey for the evaluation of the course "Computer Graphics 2" in the summer semester 2024: Computer Graphics 2: https://befragung.tu-berlin.de/evasys/online.php?p=CZ6RM  Each survey takes about half an hour and is activated until July 12th, 2024. By participating, you make an important contribution to the quality assurance of the courses offered. The more course participants take part in the survey, the more conclusive the data will be in the end.  The feedback is collected by the evaluation team of the Faculty IV and evaluated in an anonymous form. The results of the evaluation are then communicated to the lecturers via email. Mit besten Grüßen/Best regards, Gaëlle  ****************************************************************************** Gaëlle Fer-Arslan Technische Universität Berlin – Fakultät IV Institut für technische Informatik und Mikroelektronik Fachgebiet Computer Graphics – Sekr. Messages.Author: Laurin Dahm
Messages.Content: I'm not sure for what we get the Bonus Points of the bonus exercise 2. 1 Point for Ray casting and 1 point for ray marching + sphere tracing ? And do we get 2 Points for each if we implement is on the GPU (or 1 for CPU and 1 for GPU implementation)?

Messages.Author: Gabriel Alexander Dogadov
Messages.Content: You get one bonus point for ray marching on the CPU, one point for ray marching on the GPU, one point for sphere tracing on the CPU and one point for sphere tracing on the GPU. In total, you can get up to four bonus points. If you do them on the GPU, you can skip the CPU implementation (and still get full bonus points).

Messages.Content: > Do we need to Render the given implicit surfaces (generated from e.g. cat.off)  This is the point of the task: rendering the implicit surface you have generated from the given point cloud.

Messages.Author: David Barac
Messages.Content: Since today I asked the professor this question and he also could not give me an answer:  Would a clamped B-Spline not always result in a division by 0? As the very first fraction for N^{1}_{0} would result in a denominator of 0-0? Or is there some rule I am missing?

Messages.Author: Gabriel Alexander Dogadov
Messages.Content: Yes, that is correct. In this case, you can ignore the summand that contains the division by zero.

Messages.Author: Simon Thomas Thomes
Messages.Content: In the lecture, N0i is defined as: ${N^0}_i =      \begin{cases}     1 & if  t_i \leq t \leq t_{i+1}\\     0 & else\\ \end{cases} $ But shouldn't it be $t_i \leq t < t_{i+1}$ ? Because otherwise, N1i could be 2 at t = t_i+1. Or am I understanding something wrong. Best regards Simon

Messages.Author: Gabriel Alexander Dogadov
Messages.Content: Hey Simon,  While it is true that the basis functions of order are typically defined on the half-open interval , it is not necessary to do so. The reason for that is that the basis functions have a function value of zero at both boundaries of the interval, except for the first and last basis function that have a function value of one on the lower and upper boundary value, respectively. But here, all other basis functions that support the first and last knot have a function value of 0 again. Thus, they still form a partition of unity, and it is not important whether the upper boundary is contained in its supported interval or not.

Messages.Author: Gabriel Alexander Dogadov
Messages.Content: You are right. The basis functions of order zero are an exception, because they attain a constant value of one in their supported interval. This indeed contradicts the partition of unity property, since at $$t_{i+1}$$ the sum of all basis functions is two. In conclusion, the order zero basis functions should be defined on the interval $$[t_i, t_{i+1}[$$.

Messages.Author: David Koettlitz
Messages.Content: The exercise sheet states "Derive the basis functions of a first order (= degree 1) B-Spline...". Are we supposed to calculate the derivatives of all N_i^1, with i \in [0, ..., m] or should we just plug in the values for i and calculate the concrete m+1 basis functions?

Messages.Author: Gabriel Alexander Dogadov
Messages.Content: The word derive (German: "herleiten") may be a bit confusing, sorry for that. The task is to plug in the values and give an explicit expression for the basis functions. You need not compute the derivative.  EDIT: I just updated the phrasing in the exercise sheet.

Messages.Author: David Koettlitz
Messages.Content: Ok thanks! I have another question regarding B-Splines. Im a bit confused on what the domain of the basis functions should be. In the lecture, I believe it was said, that t usually is in the interval of [0, 1], but that would give weird basis functions, that are not continuous at all. On the lecture slides introducing these basis functions for B-Splines, there is written: t = (t_0, ..., t_n, t_{n+1}, ...), that t is the whole vector of the knots. But plugging in a vector for t into N_i^r(t) would produce a vector valued result of N, except at N_i^0, which produces only a scalar value. That doesn't seem right either! (for N to produce sometimes a vector and sometimes a scalar value depending on r) What is the domain of the B-Spline basis functions?

Messages.Author: Gabriel Alexander Dogadov
Messages.Content: Figuring this out is part of the task. The domain (or should I rather say support?) of each basis function depends on the domain of the functions of one order below that it was gathered from. It should not be surprising that it has something to do with the knot vector.
